title.narrative: FAO - Building Resilience in Middle Shabelle ( “BRiMS” ) 2018-2022
FAO- Building Resilience in Middle Shabelle ( “BRiMS” ) 2018-2022

description.narrative: BRiMS projektet kommer bidra till att öka motståndskraften hos utsatta människors försörjning till matosäkerhetskriser genom att hantera de bakomliggande orsaker till sårbarhet i Middle Shabelle, Somalia. Fokus området i BRiMS projektet har utsatts för återkommande torka och översvämningar. Bristen på befintlig och fungerande bevattningsinfrastruktur, utbredd osäkerhet och tillgångsutmaningar är andra utmaningar i Midle Shabelle som hämmar jordbrukarnas produktion och resulterar i försvagad motstråndskraft hos befolkningen. I ljuset av de senaste, återkommande torka och översvämningar, är den huvudsakliga fokuset på detta projekt kring vattenfrågor och bevattning: främst tillgång till vatten samt dess förvaltning.

The project will substantially increase the resilience of vulnerable people’s livelihoods to food crises by addressing key underlying causes of vulnerability in Middle Shabelle, within Somalia’s breadbasket. The area faces recurrent drought, flooding, non-functioning irrigation infrastructure, widespread insecurity and access challenges that impede farmers’ production, related supply chains and market potential. In light of recent, recurrent drought and flood emergencies, the main vulnerability addressed by the project centres on water: primarily water access, management and its productive use.

This Project is aligned with FAO’s Strategic Framework, specifically Strategic Objective 5: “Increase resilience of livelihoods to threats and crisis”. The anticipated impact of the project is “Increased resilience and production capacity for smallholder farmers in accessible areas of Middle Shabelle”.

title.narrative: 12768 - Decision on amendment of agreement - FAO BRIMS

description.narrative: The Building Resilience in Middle Shabelle (BRIMS) project was officially launched on 1 April 2019 at the federal level and at the state level on 28 July 2019. Both launches were held in Mogadishu because the state launch was unable to take place in Jowhar due to security concerns. The inception phase of the project was expected to run from 12 December 2018 to 31 July 2019 however an extension was necessary to complete the preparatory works before full implementation. The reasons behind the delay were: • Project launches and stakeholder consultations at state level delayed until after the Holy month of Ramadan• The identification and finalization of technical partners for the state level inception activities and agreement on Letter of Agreements ( LoAs ) took 4 months due to stakeholder consultations and internal compliance requirements. FAO has completed this process and signed the LoAs with 3 technical partners (ARC, STS and MUDRO) for inception phase activities. The partners have already commenced the implementation of state level inception phase activities. In addition, FAO encountered the following problems during the inception phase of this project:• Measurement of water lodged canals was a real time constraint and caused unnecessary delay while waiting for water to subside in order to accurately measure the canals;• Some farmers were resistant to take photos because of existing security concerns in the district;• Existing bushes and prosopis hinder effective measurement and require extra staff to clear the bush;• Existing government checkpoints along the river sometimes pose a challenge to staff in the field due to security operations;• Poor infrastructure hindered the movement of staff when under heavy rain. Rain caused further delays to the implementation of the activities as the NGO staff were unable to take measurements of the canals and were unable to move freely due to the poor condition of the roads. Despite the delays, the following key achievements were noted: 1. A number of assessments were completed that will inform the implementation phase. The conducted assessments include: - Assessments of canals and structures along the canals. - Capacity assessment of the existing irrigation committees and producer groups and cooperatives.- Conflict sensitivity in the project area- Resilience Index Measurement Analysis (RIMA) 2: Water management committees are established or empowered and trained (in water resource management, irrigation techniques and public asset management): Capacity assessment of existing irrigation management committees was completed during the inception phase. The assessment found existing irrigation committees in the project target area. Empowering and training the irrigation committees will start in the first quarter of 2020 and will continue until the end of the second quarter of 2020. 3: Farmers are organized into productive and profitable groups: Assessments conducted during the inception phase revealed that there are no existing farmer groups nor cooperatives in the project target area. FAO will establish new farmer groups and cooperatives starting in the first quarter of 2020.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
